meta.content: Exploring Responses of Contact Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy in Triple-Cation Double-Halide Perovskites

Hybrid organic–inorganic perovskite (HOIP) solar cells have undergone unprecedentedly rapid improvement in power conversion efficiencies during the last decade, but controversy remains regarding the role of local phenomena and heterogeneity in grain by grain. These challenges in turn necessitate understanding the fundamental mechanisms operating at individual grains and exploring how these mechanisms give rise to the collective behaviors of the films. Although numerous efforts have targeted local phenomena in these materials using classical scanning probe microscopy modalities, the measurements remain difficult to interpret due to intrinsic coupling between possible ferroelectric, ion migration, bulk and surface electrochemical phenomena, and the effects of light on these behaviors. Here, we explore the electromechanical responses in (Cs0.05FA0.85MA0.15)Pb(I0.85Br0.15)3 perovskite thin film in the dark and under illumination using band excitation-piezoresponse force microscopy (BE-PFM). To identify and separate ferroic, electrostatic, and electrochemical responses, we utilize contact-Kelvin probe force microscopy (cKPFM). The cKPFM responses show weak variability with morphological features in the dark, while such variability significantly increases under illumination. Deconvolution of the cKPFM responses via principal component analysis (PCA) shows heterogeneity in grain to grain possibly due to variation in migration and segregation of halide ions in mixed perovskites at specific grains. Further, we propose an electrostatic mechanism based on the physics of semiconductors, which can directly link the observed cKPFM behaviors with the ionic and electronic density of states (DOS) and their time dynamics. These findings suggest that cKPFM is a powerful probe of local ionic behaviors on the nanoscale, both in HOIPs and other materials.

div.div:
Hybrid organic–inorganic perovskites (HOIPs) are currently of considerable interest as they have a variety of superior semiconducting properties such as tunable band gap, large absorption coefficient, long carrier lifetime, and carrier diffusion length, which makes them promising candidates for future optoelectronic devices.
(1−5)
Since their recent rediscovery, macroscopic studies have demonstrated various effects that are largely absent in classical inorganic semiconductors. These include giant switchable photovoltaic effect,
(6)
light-induced phase segregation,
(4)
I
–
V
hysteresis,
(7−9)
and resistive switching behavior.
(10)
These phenomena have been attributed to multiple possible mechanisms, including chemical segregation,
(11)
ionic migration, accumulation of electronic and ionic charge carriers,
(12−16)
and unbalanced charge transport.
(13)

HOIP polycrystalline thin films show a rich spectrum of phenomena that are associated with both the intrinsic local and global properties, as well as interactions between individual grains and interfaces via electrostatic and strain fields affecting ionic and electronic charge transport. For example, recent study revealed that local strains caused by crystal misorientation affect both grains and grain boundaries (GBs), resulting in varying nonradiative recombination sites and consequently charge transport in HOIPs.
(17)
These local effects are also associated with the existence of charged ionic defects in dark.
(18,19)
More recently, nanoscale trap clusters were observed on the grain morphologies in HOIPs.
(20)
These inhomogeneous morphological grains stem from difference of chemical compositions between individual grains.
(20)
However, heterogeneity of grain to grain on photovoltaic properties has not yet been fully understood and a more detailed analysis is required to identify correlations between the grains in HOIPs and more importantly how to separate the nanoscale responses.

These considerations necessitate local exploration of the properties of HOIP films, typically via scanning probe microscopy (SPM) studies. The vast majority of these studies are based on the Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM), where the static or light-induced potentials on the surface are analyzed.
(14,21,22)
However, the average potential change in light-induced KPFM is a measure of photovoltaic effect, while the lateral contrast is determined by the convolution of heterogeneity of relaxation and generation rates. Another broad class of studies are based on conductive SPM,
i.e
., probing conductivity or local
I–V
characteristics.
(23,24)
Finally, ferroelectric activity was explored via piezoresponse force microscopy (PFM) techniques.
(11,25−28)
Interestingly, despite the preponderant observations of domain structures in HOIPs, their origins remain controversial. Colsmann et al.
(26,29)
have claimed that ferroelectricity is observed in HOIP films with periodic polar domains, but other results
(11,27)
have shown that ferroelastic twin domains are varied with an external stress and such domains are a chemically segregated elastic variation. Recently, it has been shown that such ferroelastic twin domains heavily influence charge carrier diffusion in MAPbI
3
,
(30)
while others argue that twin boundaries neither affect the carrier transport nor behave as nonradiative recombination sites in MAPbI
3
single crystals.
(31)
Therefore, controversy remains regarding charge transport associated with the twin domain structures. Overall, ferroic, ionic, electrochemical, and light-induced phenomena in these materials are strongly coupled and signals detected by the classical SPM modalities such as conductive atomic force microscopy (c-AFM),
(32)
KPFM, and PFM cannot reliably separate them.

Here, we explore the functional properties of the (Cs
0.05
FA
0.85
MA
0.15
)Pb(I
0.85
Br
0.15
)
3
thin films using electromechanical band excitation piezoresponse force microscopy (BE-PFM).
(33)
Details of the sample preparation are described in the Experimental Section. The mixed perovskite composition, (Cs
0.05
FA
0.85
MA
0.15
)Pb(I
0.85
Br
0.15

3
, has shown excellent photovoltaic properties, resulting in more stable solar cells with high efficiency.
(34−36)
It should be noted that the BE method allows us to detect electromechanical response across a band of frequencies centered around the contact resonance frequency of tip–sample interactions, in contrast to classical PFM that is performed at a single frequency. In this study, we observe weak electromechanical responses on the film surface in dark. The responses are higher under illumination and demonstrate strong grain by grain variability. To separate electrostatic and ionic behaviors at the grains, we apply contact-KPFM (cKPFM), a 2D analogue of the PFM and KPFM.
(37,38)
cKPFM is one of the advanced SPM techniques for exploring ferroelectric, electrostatic, and ionic signals.
(38,39)
Generally, in the cKPFM technique, we apply a complex bias waveform to the AFM tip. The bias waveform contains gradually increasing and decreasing stepwise biases with on- and off-fields. This technique allows the injection and relaxation of charge carriers, exploring whether material is ferroelectric or not.
(38)
To analyze the band dispersion and decompose complicated coupled signals obtained from cKPFM, principal component analysis (PCA) is carried out. The PCA of the average and dispersion-based descriptors of cKPFM responses in (Cs
0.05
FA

0.15

0.85
Br
0.15
)
3
thin films reveals nonlinear responses that can be attributed to the finite density of electronic and ionic states on the surface. These responses are strongly dependent on individual grains under illumination.

Band excitation (BE)-piezoresponse force microscopy (PFM) and the contact-Kelvin probe force microscopy (cKPFM) were carried out using an Asylum Research AFM (MFP-3D), with an in-house Look Instrument controller and software. A Pt-coated tip (Budget Sensors ElectriMulti75-G, 75 kHz, 3 N/m) was used for imaging and application of bias to the perovskite film surface. BE mode uses a digitally synthesized AC voltage across a range of frequencies. A built-in lock-in amplifier was used to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio in all BE-PFM and cKPFM measurements. The frequency range of the BE was centered at 380 kHz, and the amplitude for BE-PFM excitation was 2 V. The BE-PFM measurements were taken over a grid of 128 × 128 points on the sample surface. The voltage-dependent response is determined from a fit of the band excitation data to a simple harmonic oscillator (SHO) model. These signals such as amplitude, phase, resonance frequency, and quality factor (
Q
) are obtained from the SHO model method. The cKPFM measurements were taken over a grid of 40 × 40 points on the film surface. For the cKPFM measurements, a DC write voltage was applied stepwise from +1, +3 V, +1 V, −1 V, and back to + 1 V consecutively with totally 32 steps. These applied voltage steps are referred to as
V
write
. Between all
V
write
steps, there is a read bias step,
V
read
, where the piezoresponse and cKPFM response are measured with totally 11 steps. The delay time between subsequent measurements is in milliseconds. The piezoresponse measured at 0 V during the read measurements is shown in the off-field response. All measurements were carried out in the dark and under illumination using a white LED source.

Violin plot and principal component analysis (PCA) are performed using pycroscopy based on universal spectroscopy and imaging data model on Jupyter Notebook for python 3. For violin plot, kernel density estimation is used to compute an empirical distribution of the cKPFM responses. To gain PCA components and the corresponding loading maps from the standard and mean deviation of the cKPFM data, these are computed using a Scikit-Learn’s PCA estimator. This computing learns quantified data with the most important component and variations in cKPFM responses.

div.div:
As discussed above, PFM measurements provide only partial insight into the properties of the material surface. In PFM, measured signal comprises the sum of the intrinsic electromechanical response of the surface and the contact and noncontact electrostatic forces.
(42)
The noncontact electrostatic forces originate due to the local static charges between the surface and tip.
(43,44)
These forces generally scale inversely with cantilever stiffness and are nonhysteretic, albeit recently, the study by Collins et al.
(45)
demonstrated several examples of hysteretic responses due to nonlocal forces. Due to the nature of the sharp features, we suggest that the observed behaviors may be attributed to local phenomena at the tip–surface junction.

The electromechanical response (excluding electrostatics) of the surface is a sum of the inverse piezoelectric effect defined by the spontaneous polarization, effective piezoelectric coefficient, electrochemical polarization, and Vegard strains due to ionic motion and electrochemical reactions.
(46,47)
Mechanical response due to both ferroelectric and electrochemical polarization can be easily understood as a product of the polarization and electrostriction tensor,
(48)
with the ferroelectric polarization having random orientation in polycrystals and transversal orientation inside the crystals themselves, and electrochemical polarization having continuous spectrum defined by the ionic density of states of the material. It is important to note that both ferroelectric and electrochemical polarization processes are linked with ionic redistribution inside the material (within unit cell for ferroelectricity and on the length scale of screening length for electrochemistry) but do not affect the global chemistry of the material. In comparison, Vegard strain effects emerge due to the changes in local concentration of mobile ionic species due to the electrochemical process associated with ion migration across the interfaces.
(49−51)

The contact electrostatic response emerges as a result of electrostatic interaction across the tip–surface junction that acts as an additional contribution to the force acting on the tip. While the spring constant of the system is much larger in contact regime than in noncontact regimes,
(52−54)
the force is nonetheless sufficient to result in detectable response. It should be noted that the nature of the electrostatics of the tip junction is that in classical continuum description, the edge of the contact area contains essentially a singularity.
(55)
The analysis of the contact electrostatic interactions requires specific assumptions on the nature of the contact (minimal physical separation), and the estimates are very sensitive to the mesoscopic details of surface chemistry and electrochemistry. Correspondingly, the physical mechanisms behind the contact electrostatic interactions have not been generally explored.

Notably for HOIPs in which ionic, ferroic, and electrochemical phenomena coexist, electromechanical and contact electrostatic phenomena can provide valuable insight into materials functionalities if they can be separated and visualized. To achieve this goal, here, we use the cKPFM technique. In cKPFM, the tip is modulated using the complex waveform that uniformly samples the material response as a function of two parameters
V
write
and
V
read

V

V
write
is modulated as a triangular wave and
V
read

(56)
In cKPFM, the PFM spectroscopic measurements are repeated at different

Figure

V

V

For classical ferroelectrics with strong first-order bias-induced phase transition and weak polarization pinning, the size of the ferroelectric domain formed during the switching is much larger than PFM signal generation volume
(57,58)
and the PFM hysteresis loop is rectangular. In the presence of additional electrostatic phenomena, the loop will be superimposed by multiple bands. For second-order phase transitions, strong polarization pinning, etc., the cKPFM data will yield a set of tilted hysteresis loops.
(59)
Similar to techniques such as first-order reversal curve measurements,
(60)
the cKPFM signal for disordered ferroelectrics can be directly related to the Preisach density of material
(61)
(when the Preisach model is applicable).
Figure S2c–f

V
read
∼ −0.5 V. The cKPFM measurement is performed by gradually increasing and decreasing bias, where each bias step takes a few milliseconds. One possible explanation is ferroelectric polarization instability; note however that other nonferroelectric mechanisms may also be at play, including asymmetric charge relaxations.

From the discussion above, the cKPFM data set is expected to contain the rich volume of information of the ferroic and electrochemical properties of material. However, the lack of analytical models precludes the unambiguous reconstruction of materials properties in cKPFM data. Parenthetically, this limitation is universal for most SPM techniques even including simple
I-V

The purely separated response in spatial distribution at the nanoscale via PCA confirms grain-to-grain heterogeneity in the film surface. Classical KPFM do not precisely measure the CPD between two materials as the tip and the surface are always separated by an air or vacuum gap. Thus, junction CPD (jCPD) was previously proposed using the cKPFM technique.

When CPD and jCPD are the same at metal–metal junction due to no passivating effect while junction dynamics induced by electrochemical reaction, ionic motion, and complex charge behaviors lead to differences between CPD and jCPD. div.div:
To summarize, the spatial variability of bias-dependent electromechanical behaviors in the (Cs
0.05
FA
0.85
MA
0.15
)Pb(I
0.85
Br
0.15
)
3
perovskite thin film is explored in the dark and under illumination using BE-PFM and cKPFM, systematically probing the electromechanical responses as a function of instant and preceding probe bias. For this mixed perovskite composition, the general cKPFM behavior was found to give rise to a banded response, with the systematic variation of the bandwidth and mean behavior across the sample surface. We found that cKPFM responses are strongly dependent to individual grains. A local heterogeneity was observed within some of the grains across the film; however, a clear dynamic cannot be found between grains. Such behavior is significantly enhanced under illumination. Converting data to violin plots reveals a clear band dispersion and response density in the cKPFM results. Data acquisition via PCA indicates that cKPFM responses are dependent on the grains as a function of applied bias, especially for the read bias (
V
read
). CPD variations in the first component in PCA is faintly dependent on grains in the dark, while they are strongly associated with grains under illumination possibly due to migration and segregation of halide ions at the specific grains. However, light-driven CPD enhancement does not occur at all grains due to morphological heterogeneity. This result suggests that the homogeneous grains with high CPD via chemical and strain engineering could be one of the important keys for high-efficiency perovskite solar cells.

It is shown that CH3NH3PbI3-based perovskites exhibit intrinsic properties that are superior for solar cell applications: extremely high optical absorption; small effective masses for electrons and holes; dominant point defects that only generate shallow levels and grain boundaries that are benign. These unique properties can be understood from the perovskite symmetry and Pb lone-pair 6s orbitals. The results explain why CH3NH3PbI3 related materials have long electron-hole diffusion lengths and their thin-film solar cells can achieve high efficiencies and high open-circuit voltages. This also point the way towards achieving even higher efficiencies through metal or/and halogen element alloying.

Organolead halide perovskites are an impressive and relatively recent class of light-absorbing materials for solar cells and light-emitting devices. It has been reported that exposure of perovskite materials to light has neg. impacts on device performance. Also, surface recombination has been reported as a major obstacle to the total carrier lifetime in perovskite polycryst. thin films. Herein, the authors explored the role played by nanosecond pulsed UV laser-irradn. in carrier dynamics in perovskite thin films. Steady-state and time-resolved photoluminescence measurements revealed the interplay of disorder and heterogeneity on photoexcited carrier dynamics, while in situ micro Raman spectroscopy and angle dispersive x-ray diffraction showed the mechanisms of crystal phase reconstruction. Exposure to laser light leads to rapid crystal phase reconstruction and hence, unexpectedly, extends the PL lifetime by fourfold instead of promoting degrdn. This verifies that nanosecond pulsed laser irradn. plays a beneficial role in improving optoelectronic material parameters. The authors' findings reveal that pulsed laser irradn. is a new approach to the reconstruction of the microstructure and offers beneficial effects in the manuf. of perovskite solar cells. Moreover, this work provides a clear insight towards identifying the phys. origin behind the disorder, heterogeneity, film reconstruction and nano-structuring as well as their correlation with improved PL lifetimes.

A review. Materials with highly cryst. lattice structures and low defect concns. have classically been considered essential for high-performance optoelectronic devices. However, the emergence of high-efficiency devices based on halide perovskites is provoking researchers to rethink this traditional picture, as the heterogeneity in several properties within these materials occurs on a series of length scales. Perovskites are typically fabricated crudely through simple processing techniques, which leads to large local fluctuations in defect d., lattice structure, chem. and bandgap that appear on short length scales (<100 nm) and across long ranges (>10 μm). Despite these variable and complex non-uniformities, perovskites maintain exceptional device efficiencies and are, as of 2018, the best-performing polycryst. thin-film solar cell material. In this Review, we highlight the multiple layers of heterogeneity ascertained using high-spatial-resoln. methods that provide access to the relevant length scales. We discuss the impact that the optoelectronic variations have on halide perovskite devices, including the prospect that it is this very disorder that leads to their remarkable power-conversion efficiencies.
